case_name: Mysore State Road Transport Corporation v. Respondent

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1299 of 1967 was filed by the Corporation.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 1299 of 1967. Appeal by special leave from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated November 16, 1966 of the Mysore High Court in Writ Petition No. 1464 of 1964.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated November 16, 1966 of the Mysore High Court in Writ Petition No. 1464 of 1964.

facts.text: The respondent was a class III employee in the statistical department of the Mysore State Road Transport Corporation.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent was a class III employee in the statistical department of the Mysore State Road Transport Corporation.

facts.text: In October 1961, the respondent was temporarily promoted to act as statistical superintendent at Hassan.

anchor.surface_text: In October 1961, he was temporarily promoted to act as statistical superintendent at Hassan.

facts.text: On July 21, 1964, the General Manager of the Corporation issued a notice inviting applications for appointments to class II junior posts of assistant divisional statisticians and labour welfare officers on a pay of Rs. 220 per month in the pay scale of Rs. 220-15-400-EB-20-500 plus allowances.

anchor.surface_text: On July 21, 1964, the General Manager of the Corporation issued a notice inviting applications for appointments to class 11 junior posts of  a  assistant divisional statisticians and  b  labour welfare officers on a pay of Rs. 220 per month in the pay scale of Rs. 220-15-400-EB-20-500 plus the usual dearness and other allowances admissible under the Rules.

facts.text: On August 11, 1964, the respondent filed a writ petition in the High Court at Mysore claiming that the Corporation had no power to issue the notice and praying for an order quashing it.

anchor.surface_text: On August 11, 1964, the respondent filed a writ petition in the High Court at Mysore claiming that the Corporation had no power to issue the notice and praying for an order quashing it.

facts.text: The High Court allowed the petition and quashed the notice.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court allowed the petition and quashed the notice.

facts.text: The Corporation filed this appeal by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: The Corporation has filed this appeal by special leave.

facts.text: No regulations were framed by the Corporation under s. 45(2)(c) prescribing the conditions of appointment and service and the scales of pay of its officers and servants.

anchor.surface_text: Admittedly, no regulations were framed by the Corporation under s. 45 2  c  prescribing the conditions of appointment and service and the scales of pay of its officers and servants.

facts.text: In the affidavit filed on behalf of the Corporation, it was stated that the Corporation was taking necessary steps for the framing of the regulations.

anchor.surface_text: In the affidavit filed on behalf of the Corporation, it was stated that the Corporation was taking necessary steps for the framing of the regulations.

facts.text: The High Court held that until regulations were framed by the Corporation under s. 45(2)(c) with the previous sanction of the State Government, the Corporation could not appoint officers and servants and lay down their conditions of service.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court following its earlier decision in Karnakar Mangesha Desai v. State of Mysore and others 1  held that until regulations were framed by the Corporation under s. 45 2  c  with the previous sanction of the State Government, the Corporation could not appoint officers and servants and lay down their conditions of service.

facts.text: The Supreme Court held that the judgment of the High Court is erroneous and should be set aside.

anchor.surface_text: We think that the judgment of the High Court is erroneous and should be set aside.

facts.text: There is no merit in the contention that the General Manager had no power to issue the notice dated July 21, 1964 in the absence of any resolution by the Corporation under s.12(c) expressly authorising him.

anchor.surface_text: There is no merit in the further contention that the General Manager had no power to issue the notice dated July 21, 1964 in the absence of any resolution by the Corporation under s.12 c  expressly authorising him to issue it.

facts.text: The respondent contended that he had the right to be promoted to a class II junior post.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent also contended that he had the right to be promoted to a class II junior post.

facts.text: There is nothing on the record to show that the respondent has any vested right of promotion to the post.

anchor.surface_text: But there is nothing on the record to show that he has any vested right of promotion to the post.

facts.text: Civil Miscellaneous Petition No. 3032 of 1967 filed by the respondent asking for liberty to adduce additional evidence and to raise new contentions is dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Miscellaneous Petition No. 3032 of 1967 filed by the respondent asking for liberty to adduce additional evidence and to raise new contentions is dismissed.

facts.text: In the order dated August 17, 1967 granting special leave to the appellant, the Court directed that the appellant must pay the costs of the respondent in any event.

anchor.surface_text: In the order dated August 17, 1967 granting special leave to the appellant, the Court directed that the appellant must pay the costs of the respondent in any event.

facts.text: The appeal is allowed, the order of the High Court is set aside and the writ petition is dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the appeal is allowed, the order of the High Court is set aside and the writ petition is dismissed.

facts.text: The appellant shall pay the costs of the appeal to the respondent pursuant to the order dated August 17, 1967.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant shall pay the costs of the appeal to the respondent pursuant to the order dated August 17, 1967.
Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated November 16, 1966 of the Mysore High Court in Writ Petition No. 1464 of 1964.
Writ Petition No. 1464 of 1964.

14 1 . Every Corporation shall have a Chief Executive Officer or General Manager and a Chief Accounts Officer appointed by the State Government.  2  A Corporation may appoint such other officers and servants as it companysiders necessary for the efficient performance of its functions. The companyditions of appointment and service and the scales of pay of the officers and servants of a Corporation shall-  a  as respects the Chief Executive Officer or General Manager and the Chief Accounts Officer be such as may be prescribed, and  b  as respects the other officers and servants be such as may, subject to the provisions of section 34, be determined by regulations made under this Act.

concepts.interpretation: Section 14(2) expressly confers upon the Corporation the incidental power to appoint such officers and servants as it considers necessary for the efficient performance of its functions. Section 14(3)(b) provides that conditions shall be determined by regulations subject to s.34.

concepts.unlisted_description: Powers and conditions of appointment of officers and servants

anchor.surface_text: 19 1 . Subject to the provisions of this Act, a Corporation shall have power.  a  to operate road transport services in the State and in any extended area  b  to provide for any ancillary service-,  c  to provide for its employees suitable companyditions of service including fair wages, establishment of provident fund, living accommodation, places for rest and recreation and other amenities.

concepts.interpretation: Section 19(1)(c) empowers it to provide for its employees suitable conditions of service.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: o the directions, if any, given by the State Government under s.34 and the regulations, if any, framed under s.45 2  c . But until such regulations ar

concepts.unlisted_description: Powers of Corporation including conditions of service for employees

anchor.surface_text: 34 1 . The State Government may, after companysultation with a Corporation established by such Government give to the Corporation general instructions to be followed by the Corporation, and such instructions may include directions relating to the recruitment, companyditions of service and training of its employees, wages to be paid to the employees, reserves to be maintained by it and disposal of its profits or stocks. In the exercise of its powers and performance of its duties under this Act, the Corporation shall number depart from any general instructions issued under sub-section  1  except with the previous permission of the State Government.

concepts.interpretation: If the State Government issues any directions under s.34 relating to recruitment and conditions of service, the Corporation must obey those directions. The joint effect of ss.14(3)(b),34 and 45(2)(c) is that appointment and conditions must conform to directions under s.34 and regulations under s.45(2)(c).

C. said The answer to the question whether a company oration created by a statute has a particular power depends exclusively on whether that power has been expressly given to it by the statute regulating it, or can be implied from the language used. The question is simply one of companystruction of language, and lot of presumption.

issues.text: whether the appellant had the power to appoint officers and servants and to lay down their conditions of service in the absence of regulations framed under s. 45(2)(c) of the Road Transport Corporation Act, 1950

arguments.claim: the joint effect of ss.14(3)(b),34 and 45(2)(c) is that the appointment of officers and servants and their conditions of service must conform to the directions, if any, given by the State Government under s.34 and the regulations, if any, framed under s.45(2)(c)

anchor.surface_text: The joint effect of ss.14 3  b ,34 and 45 2  c  is that the appointment of officers and servants and their conditions of service must conform to the directions, if any, given by the State Government under s.34 and the regulations, if any, framed under s.45 2  c .

arguments.claim: until such regulations are framed or directions are given, the Corporation may appoint such officers or servants as may be necessary for the efficient performance of its duties on such terms and conditions as it thinks fit

anchor.surface_text: But until such regulations are framed or directions are given. the Corporation may appoint such officers or servants as may be necessary for the efficient performance of its duties on such terms and conditions as it thinks fit.

arguments.claim: there is necessarily a time-lag between the formation of the Corporation and the framing of regulations under s. 45(2)(c); during the intervening period, the Corporation must carry on the administration with the help of officers and servants

anchor.surface_text: There is necessarily a time- lag between the formation of the Corporation and the framing of regulations under s. 45 2  c . During the intervening period, the Corporation must carry on the administration of its affairs with the help of officers and servants.

arguments.claim: in the absence of clear words, it is difficult to impute to the legislature the intention that the Corporation would have no power to appoint officers and servants and fix the conditions of service unless the regulations under s.45(2)(c) are framed

anchor.surface_text: In the absence of clear words, it is difficult to impute to the legislature the intention that the Corporation would have no power to appoint officers and servants and fix the conditions of service unless the regulations under s.45 2  c  are framed.

In the result, the appeal is allowed, the order of the High Court is set aside and the writ petition is dismissed. The appellant shall pay the costs of the appeal to the respondent pursuant to the order dated August 17, 1967.

edges.explanation: Precedent citing 'until regulations framed under s.45(2)(c)' supports the no-power-until-regs argument.

Precedent from Dundee Harbour Trustees establishes the concept of express or implied powers of a statutory corporation from the language of the statute, enabling a narrower reading that implies appointment powers without explicit regulations.
Precedent on statutory corporation powers supports addressing the issue through implied powers reading down.
